title: What will the long-term interest rate be for Colombia (COL) in August 2017?
preds: The country is in relatively good shape, but economic variables look unstable. I guess most likely is that it will stay where it is.

Into political election cycle... easing has ended. Stats are fuzzy. Somewhat misleading term "long term interest rate"... do you mean the interest rate on the 10 year bond? Need to be more clear.  No wonder Harry Truman wanted to work with a one handed economist so he wouldn't have to hear this breed of "social scientist" say... on the other hand.

Hasn't been above 7.14% since December 2016.  Right now, 7.04%. But it recently was below 6.93%. Why? @melancholy-aeon provides data and an analysis that supports increasing the probability of between 6.7% and 6.93% at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/556075.

I think people are mixing up short term interest rates with Long term Interest rates in their forecasts.
See below.
"Long-term interest rates refer to government bonds maturing in ten years. Rates are mainly determined by the price charged by the lender, the risk from the borrower and the fall in the capital value. Long-term interest rates are generally averages of daily rates, measured as a percentage. These interest rates are implied by the prices at which the government bonds are traded on financial markets, not the interest rates at which the loans were issued. In all cases, they refer to bonds whose capital repayment is guaranteed by governments. " Track here:
https://www.investing.com/rates-bonds/colombia-10-year-bond-yield

The recently signed and still honoured peace treaty with FARC appears to be improving the investment climate in Colombia, and barring serious provocations (unlikely, as both sides appear to be benefitting from the arrangement), long term interest rates are highly likely to continue to fall.

"The central bank has cut 225 basis points from the benchmark rate since the trimming cycle began in December, leaving it at 5.50 percent last month. Recent surveys of economists by Reuters and the central bank found that policymakers would likely cut the rate by another 25 basis points in August and then hold it through the end of the year. Cuts would continue in 2018 to bring it to 4.50 percent." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-latam-summit-ocampo-idUSKBN1AR1L9 Interest rates overall are coming down in Colombia due to slowing inflation.  The OECD forecast was 5.8. https://data.oecd.org/interest/short-term-interest-rates-forecast.htm
Quarterly OECD forecast was 6.22 https://data.oecd.org/interest/short-term-interest-rates.htm Daily overnight interbank rates fell to 5.4 on Aug. 22 https://tradingeconomics.com/colombia/interbank-rate Daily Colombia repo rate steady at 5.50 according to Bloomberg https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CORRRMIN:IND And finally looking at the daily numbers themselves on Investing for the average: https://www.investing.com/rates-bonds/colombia-10-year-bond-yield We see short and long term rates drifting down in Colombia. Thus my prediction is  different than other forecasters here based on this economic policy & trading data.
Colombia will wait until something happens in Venezuela before moving on interest rates.  So, its current rate holds for the coming month.

Based on comparison of OECD and Trading Econ data differences:
https://tradingeconomics.com/colombia/government-bond-yield

The Colombian long-term interest rate has ranged from 7.61% in July of last year to 7.03% in July of this year.  The decreasing rate indicates improving stability in a historically volatile state.  If the landmark deal with FARC holds steady, Colombia will likely continue to improve and interest rates will drop at a slow rate.  With the current political climate in Colombia, I believe we will see a tenth or so drop in the long-term interest rate.

On average since 2014 the rate has moved 0.27 % on a monthly basis. The average rate over August seems to be slightly higher than in July, though there has been a decreasing trend over the past few weeks. https://www.investing.com/rates-bonds/colombia-10-year-bond-yield
The expectation is that there will be a rating cut by the end of the year, which might be priced in now, hence raising the governments financing cost. The general outlook for Latin America has been negative recently due to slumping commodity prices. https://www.cnbc.com/2017/07/18/reuters-america-colombias-fiscal-outlook-puts-investment-credit-rating-at-risk.html
The data from the OECD  seems to be around 0.2 -0.3 % higher than the data from https://tradingeconomics.com/colombia/government-bond-yield .  So if thing don't move to much it should be around 7%.

Hard to say how this will play out for August. While it has seen a minor increase in the past couple months, in general the trend over the past 1.5 years has been a decrease (since the peace deal with the FARC became more of a reality). Given this trend, I think it's more likely to drop back down. However, the monthly volatility means I have to account for the rate maintaining, or possibly increasing further.
The long-term interest rate has been relatively stable over recent months and there is not obvious reason to consider a sudden change.  I'm going with a conservative change option
Believe the trajectory of last two months will be maintained barring any unforeseen events.

This is a tough one, the rate bounces around quite a bit but luckily the swings aren't huge each month. That said, I think the rate in the short term is determined mostly by fundamentals combined with recent news. Since the FARC has surrendered their weapons I think, in the short term, the outlook for Columbia's future is brighter.

Statistical methods aren't the most helpful with the data set. Didn't want to bother with economic models. I looked at the average of month-to-month increases and decreases to get a sense how much movement typically happens month to month. In the last eight months - the central bank lowered the discount rate at the end of July for the 8th straight month - only one adjustment would have stayed within the same band from month to month. Thus the low probably of staying the same. I think downward is more likely than upward from a quick review of some macro fundamentals. A lot of this is probably a guess.
@Intriligator:   estimates calculated for an August forecast indicate that the predicted value of long term interest rates in Columbia will be around 5%.
